Then Iâ€™m struck with empathy. Itâ€™s not their fault, right? If my Mom had an abusive parent (though she claims vehemently that she didnâ€™t-but she must have! Right? Otherwise how could a mother be this way?) then she couldnâ€™t help herself and should be met with compassion. Then I think of all the ways I went above and beyond, sacrificed so much to show her said compassion, and still at the end she lied and stole from me, lied about meâ€¦ but itâ€™s so fucked up that it canâ€™t actually be her fault!
Thoughts like this go round and round in my head, day in and day out. Iâ€™m exhausted.
Iâ€™ve gathered some numbers of therapists to call who specialize in ptsd. My night terrors have gotten so bad that I wake the family up at night screaming. My husband doesnâ€™t sleep, just like I donâ€™t. The nightmares are constant. Iâ€™ve cut off contact from my mother, yet her programming lingers. And even still I wonderâ€¦ am I to blame? Was I a bad child? I donâ€™t feel like I was. I feel like I was a loving and tender child, wanting the best for everyone. Butâ€”two thoughts hereâ€”one, if my mother is crazy enough to use and abuse her own child, to allow us to be on their own for days on end with dirty clothes and no food, to yell at us when we tried to do something good like clean the kitchen or soothe the babyâ€¦ if she could be that damaged, perhaps I am as well and I donâ€™t know that even though I think Iâ€™m a compassionate and kind person, that actually perhaps Iâ€™m truly awful. My mother thinks sheâ€™s an empath, a woman with special spiritual powers. She often tells me she did her best, loved me to death. If she could believe that, then how can I be sure of my own sanity, when she seems so sure of hers? Secondly, my mother often told me I had a bad memory, created false memories. Content:
Last night I did something quite unique. I went to a tantric sensuality event. My best friend Kristin is a sex worker. She does whatâ€™s called Tantric Massage. Kristin just off hand asked me if I wanted to go to a party as her guest on Friday and I said yes, I would absolutely love to. Iâ€™m so, so glad she asked me because I had such a blast! Sometimes when Iâ€™ve been to parties in penthouses, Iâ€™ve been bored to tears. When I was modeling, I found myself in many luxurious settings just filled to the brim with the dullest people Iâ€™ve ever met, so I wasnâ€™t exactly sure what to expect when I walked through the door.
They had demonstrations every hour or so in the middle of the room, where Kristin and her cohorts gave live massages while everyone watched on pillows. I, of course, just watched without engaging. I did give random lady a scalp massage, and that was fun. I just saw her on the table being massaged by someone else and I asked if sheâ€™d like one. I miss giving them at the salon, so it was fun to do that for someone. And then there was a massage train and I just massaged Kristinâ€™s back for a while. Nothing crazy, nothing sexual. I wish the world was more open to respectful, loving touch. Itâ€™s a real shame that polite society doesnâ€™t allow for just regular old human to human contact. I just love touching other people and being touched, plain and simple. I guess thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m a hairdresser now that I think about it. Our society is so obsessed with sin, and sinful pleasures, blah blah blah. Touching leads to this which leads to that and all roads point to Hell and eternal damnation. *eye roll* I think we would all suffer a lot less mental pain if we hugged and touched each other more. At one point we were watching a demonstration and there was an older couple to my left in each otherâ€™s arms. The lady and I just held hands while we watched the demo and her man held her and rubbed her shoulders, stroked her hair. Then we just said thank you and I got up and walked on to take in the view of the skyline on the patio for a while. Such a beautiful, pure little moment.
Anyhow! Additionally, God, it was just so nice to be around real adults. Real, smart, accomplished, respectful, intelligent, open minded adults.
On that note, itâ€™s Michaelâ€™s birthday today. He didnâ€™t want a party, he requested an all day jam session with his band. So theyâ€™ve been at it since about 1pm. Itâ€™s 10:30 now. Iâ€™m very happy for him because it makes him very happy. Itâ€™s palpable. He really enjoys it. Unfortunately, the flip side for me is I do not enjoy it. Let me explain.
I come from music. My parents met on the road in the 70s. My dad has a #1 and multiple top 20 billboard cuts. I grew up around industry professionals and spent a lot of time in professional recording studios when I was younger. Those are some of my fondest memories with my father. Beyond that I had a musical career myself. My own band. Iâ€™ve been in many other bands. Touring, session work.
My husband, bless himâ€¦ He doesnâ€™t know what this is like. He thinks that heâ€™s a professional now. He thinks because heâ€™s recorded a handful of people in his garage and had a long term gig as a house band at a small bar in Orange County, that makes him professional. And to be fair, Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s not wrong. The problem is I know what top tier professionalism is, and he is not that. His accomplishments, though valid, are not â€¦ Look, Iâ€™m not shitting on his music, or his recording projects. The problem is I see them for what they are, which is just that: projects.
The people in his band are amateurs. I mean literal amateurs. The bass player is a 30 something year old guy who works at Taco Bell and just started playing bass 6 months ago. The singer is a 20 year old girl who, though tremendously talented, has such deep insecurities and anxiety, itâ€™s difficult to be around for too long before I find my own anxiety and panic is triggered. I mean, this girl trembles, and has one of those extra loud, constant nervous-laughs after every sentence she musters. I had to tell her to calm down just now when I brought the cake out, because Michael suggested they play the song theyâ€™ve been working up today and she almost wouldnâ€™t do it.
â€œGuys, Iâ€¦ I just canâ€™t. I donâ€™t think I can. Guys, Iâ€¦ come on, I canâ€™t do it. I donâ€™t have the juice. I canâ€™t do this live, guys.â€ It was nauseating. Like, I just wanted to be like, â€œDude, look around you. Youâ€™re literally in a garage. Shut the fuck up and just sing, and if you donâ€™t have anything, make something up, and if you donâ€™t want to make something up, then donâ€™t. But stop. Just stop. Itâ€™s just a jamâ€¦ in a garage. Get ahold of yourself.â€ But of course I didnâ€™t, nor would I.
But itâ€™s just really hard. Itâ€™s not that Iâ€™m judging them, like oh these kids suck. Whatâ€™s difficult for me is that it reminds me of when I was 15 and in little bands with other kids. And now, Iâ€™m 36 years old. Thereâ€™s something about being around grown adults who still do bong rips and work at Taco Bell that is just so depressing to me. I mean, itâ€™s just so sad. I find it triggering.
I know Iâ€™ve talked about this before, but itâ€™s really something that I struggle with. Itâ€™s really hard for me to smile and be supportive, when I want to be likeâ€¦ uhhâ€¦. itâ€™s okay, I guess? I mean, it would be more than okay if they were kids. But theyâ€™re not. Theyâ€™re adults. If they were kids, Iâ€™d be like fuck yes you guys, keep going, youâ€™re doing great. But everyone in there is just soooo insecure. Quite frankly, I find it annoying, dare I say pathetic. I miss being around people who are confident! People who play their unfinished work in progress and look to me with proud assurance, not for reassurance, which is so hard for me to give! Because, like I said, the music isnâ€™t great. The players are bad. The drummer is patheticâ€“oh god, side note. This guy is so ridiculous. This is the friend who works at a restaurant and is betting all his horses on this band being â€œsuccessful,â€ whatever the fuck that means to him. And that would be fine, except he canâ€™t perform. Iâ€™ve never, ever, in my 3 years of knowing him, ever seen him get through a song without several fuck-ups. Anyhow, he showed up today and his hair is so long because heâ€™s too fucking lazy to get a haircut. Iâ€™ve given him his last two haircuts because I just couldnâ€™t stand it. And I did it at first to be polite, but now I think heâ€™s come to expect it, which isnâ€™t surprising because this same pattern happened with another one of his deadbeat friends, Danny. He showed up today with this absolutely absurd slick-back hair do that is justâ€¦ itâ€™s hard to look at!
Why donâ€™t people understand that if you want to be respected in this world, you need to take care of yourself. I donâ€™t mean you need to have expensive clothes and a fancy barber haircut every 2 weeks. But for Godâ€™s sake man, get a fucking haircut! You look like a clown! Have some respect for yourself! Jesus itâ€™s justâ€¦ I canâ€™t be around these people. I literally canâ€™t stomach it. It makes me feel bad to be around them. I get no joy. I have to dumb myself down, I have to act impressed at the slightest little effort. I just canâ€™t relate to them in any way. I tried, Lord knows I did. But at the end of the day, being around them makes me feel yucky. Their anxiety becomes my anxiety. Their lack of confidence affects me physically. I choose to be around people who bring me life and energy. People who laugh and donâ€™t take shit. People who go out and do things.
In life, the company that you keep is extremely important. If you hang out with deadbeats, you will become a deadbeat. Even if you arenâ€™t, people will look at the people you associate with, and if youâ€™re associating with lazy grown adults who canâ€™t even bother to get a haircut more than twice a year, who still live with their parents and work at Taco Bell, I meanâ€¦ You just have to do better. You have to.
I prefer to hang out with confident, driven, ambitious, successful, honest, cultured people. Iâ€™m not at all without compassion for people who are struggling. Iâ€™m well acquainted with struggle. But I have little sympathy for those who just donâ€™t try. The time for associating with people who donâ€™t value themselves, work at Taco Bell (Not for lack of work either! this guy has a Masterâ€™s degree! He just wonâ€™t get a decent job. Itâ€™s literally his choice. How sad is that!) The time for that is over. The time for that is in your late teens to early 20s. So itâ€™s hard for me to not look at Michael and just be disappointed he chooses to associate with people like this. Like, this isnâ€™t just his band. These are his people. He talks to them in a group chat all day long every day. And I really, really hate feeling this way. I really hate it. I want to be proud of him. By most accounts I am proud of him! But the fact that he chooses to do this for 10 hours while I watch the baby, it makes me sad.
If it was just a hobby, if he and his friends were just having fun and getting their kicks, I could respect that. But theyâ€™re super â€œseriousâ€. I put quotations around it because they have no idea what being in a serious band and being a serious musician even looks like, so the fact that theyâ€™re acting like theyâ€™re taking this so seriously is hard to stomach.
Sometimes I canâ€™t tell if venting about this is helpful or not. I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m reinforcing a negative thought pattern. The PTSD book I read though encouraged verbal ventilation to deal with emotions, particularly negative emotions. That stuffing them down and acting like theyâ€™re not there is not healthy, as the body retains these truths. So I release them here. It does help tremendously, and I feel super relieved afterwards, even though I also feel guilty. Itâ€™s hard to allow myself to be aware that I have negative feelings in this way. I feel like Iâ€™m doing something wrong. Thatâ€™s part of my childhood programming. I know that itâ€™s not hurting anyone, and in fact itâ€™s helpful because I donâ€™t feel like a valve ready to burst when I go back and visit for a few minutes with them all. I wish I could be a perfect person with only lovely, happy kind thoughts 100% of the time, but I know thatâ€™s not fair and itâ€™s not real.

C: Yes, wellâ€¦ yes.

If coming here is an issue, then we will come to you. Itâ€™s no problem. I donâ€™t want you to take this as Iâ€™m angry or Iâ€™m coming down on you, I just want you to know that itâ€™s very serious and it just canâ€™t continue, for Michaelâ€™s sake and the sake of my son.
And the lying needs to stop. No more â€œIâ€™ll be there in 30 minutesâ€ wonâ€™t be here for 2 hours. No more, â€œIâ€™ve been driving 4 minutes,â€ when youâ€™re not even in the car. I have a baby and I cannot operate like that. My son is on a schedule. Iâ€™m a very understanding person, but I do not appreciate being lied to. Itâ€™s just unnecessary. Just be honest. If youâ€™re not going to be here til 3, then just say so. But the little lies are very confusing, and frankly, itâ€™s not right.
Okay? Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re here. Iâ€™m sad youâ€™re leaving. I thought we would have dinner together, and Iâ€™m sad to see you go.
(Then the conversation took a bizarre twist.)
C: Yes, well itâ€™s very nice that we get to meet here at the house.
Me: Iâ€™m sorry?
C: I just love this house. You know, I grew up in it. I mean, it was Alisonâ€™s house she grew up in, but I was born 3 years before her so Iâ€™ve been here the longest.
*Okay, at this point, I had no idea what to say, or what she was talking about. She lives in a house that sheâ€™s been in since the 70â€™s, so why she was referring to my home as â€œthe family houseâ€? It seemed loaded to me. I got the sense that she felt it belonged to her, which made me very uncomfortable. And the assertion that it was somehow more her house than Alisonâ€™s (Michaelâ€™s mom) also made me uncomfortable. But again, giving the benefit of the doubt, and just trying to understand, I just asked her to elaborate.
Me: Okayâ€¦? Iâ€™d love to hear more about that.

Me: Okay, well Iâ€™m glad that you feel that way and you know youâ€™re welcome to come here any time at all. Any time, Christie. It doesnâ€™t have to be a special occasion.
C: Well I better get going.
So, regardless of the particulars of this specific situation, Iâ€™m really proud of myself for how I handled it. In the past I would let my emotions over power me, take the baits, allow myself to get confused, people-please. But this time, I didnâ€™t. I showed strength and compassion, as well as clearly set my boundaries and where and when I expect to be respected.
I talked to Michael about it and he gave me some insight. He said that Christie is a hoarder. We went to her house once and just sat on the porch the whole time. He said her house is falling apart, so he has the feeling that rather than fix her own problems, she thinks she should have this house instead because itâ€™s beautiful and clean. Thereâ€™s a lot of family members who think they should have this house instead of Michael. He inherited it from his grandfather, and a wise choice that was.

I mean, this house was royally fucked up when I came along, so much so that I almost refused to move in when Michael asked. There were holes, literal holes in the floor. The paint was all cracked and yellow. The baseboards were black from dirt. The bathroom didnâ€™t even have a toilet paper holder. There were holes in the walls. There were holes in the ceiling! God knows how that happened, but yeah. There was piles and piles and piles of shit just everywhere. The entire patio was filled to the brim with old, broken, dusty shit. The yard was a wreck. The grass was patchy and the vines had grown up all over everything so there was tons of bugs. I meanâ€¦ it was gnarly. It really was.
But over 3 and a half years, Michael and I have made it into something really beautiful. We got the floors fixed and refinished. We had the whole house repainted, got all new baseboards. We installed a dishwasher. I fixed the bathroom up really nice with matching accessories and hooks and things. We have beautiful, interesting furniture. I painted accent walls. I have all my plants and hanging lights out there, Michael hung a TV on the ceiling that folds down, so itâ€™s just lovely. Weâ€™ve slowly fixed the yard up, with rose bushes and trimmed back all the wild vines to find really beautiful old plants his grandma had installed probably in the 70s that were vying to survive. I mean, itâ€™s been a thing, and weâ€™re not done yet. So I get the feeling that people forget that it was a piece of shit, and now they just see how beautiful it is, and theyâ€™re angry because they want a beautiful house too, but wonâ€™t do the hard work to make that happen for themselves.
And itâ€™s so sad because his family could come over here and we could have lovely times together. I thought his mother would look around with pride and feel joy that the house she grew up in is finally being restored and treated with respect. But instead weâ€™re met with jealousy and strange passive aggressive comments. His father is so angry he wouldnâ€™t let him move in when he became homeless due to drug use and losing his job, that heâ€™s not speaking to Michael at the moment. Alison feels bad that Becky didnâ€™t inherit a house, so she just pays her rent, even though sheâ€™s a grown woman in her 30s. Christie says things like, â€œIâ€™ve been here the longest,â€ instead of, â€œThank you so much for having me. I love being here. This place is special and itâ€™s nice to see it being treated as such.â€ Nope. None of that. Alison is always telling me ideas she has for remodeling even though she doesnâ€™t live here, because she wants to, in her words, up the market value. But really itâ€™s because she wants to feel like she has some say over what goes on here, even though she doesnâ€™t live here. Her ideas are so strange and convoluted, just like she is. The â€œrenovationsâ€ she made while she had the house briefly are so bizarre that weâ€™ve spent thousands undoing the damage she did. Lord, help me.
Anyhow, thatâ€™s all for now, and definitely enough!Â ğŸ˜‚ Iâ€™ve been typing for hours.
Back to the original point, I feel good today. Iâ€™ve been really struggling with deep depression the last several weeks in a row, which can be just exhausting. Normally, situations like this would further that, because I feel powerless and hurt.
It feels really good. Iâ€™m really glad I started this journal. Itâ€™s really helped me get in touch with myself and sort my thoughts. Until next time!

This Motherâ€™s Day I was holding out some hope that my sisters might send me a message or call me, but they didnâ€™t.

I have to keep reminding myself that this loneliness hurts but itâ€™s because Iâ€™m clearing space for good people and healthy relationships that will form in the future.
Iâ€™m constantly fighting to see the bright side of things and itâ€™s exhausting.
Yesterday was Motherâ€™s Day proper and even though I didnâ€™t hear from my family, I got texts all day long from all my friends, even people I hadnâ€™t spoken to in a while! It made me feel so, so good. I have to focus on that, and not let what didnâ€™t happen be what I focus on.
Sometimes I feel like such a sad sack when I write these diary entries. The more I dig and uncover, the more and more shit comes up to deal with underneath each layer. Itâ€™s a tiring gig, kids!
Part of the tiring part is constantly fighting my internal programming and finding trust in myself. I want to surrender and say Iâ€™m sorry though I didnâ€™t do anything wrong just to â€œkeep the peaceâ€ and feel some semblance of love. They treat me like a piece of human shit, and they like it!
